question: Coffee?
answer: Yeah... Thank you.

question: How have you liked your stay?
answer: What I've seen...I've liked.

question: Please to explain, why I should agree to interview...with pro-Zionist American media?
answer: Because I think Hezbollah is trying to broaden into a political party right now. So you care about what you're thought of in America. And in America, at this moment in time, Hezbollah does not have a face. That's why.

question: Perhaps you prove journalism objectivity and I see the questions first. Then I decide if I grant the interview.
answer: No. We don't do that. You've seen "60 Minutes" and Mike Wallace. So you know our reputation for integrity and objectivity. You also know we are the highest-rated, most-respected, TV-magazine news show in America.

question: Tell him I will see him day after tomorrow.
answer: That's good. That works. Uh, you know, I want to ask you something...I know it sounds odd...but... Hello, Sheikh...? Hello, Sheikh...? Norman. Take your blindfold off. Welcome to the world. Mike, it's me. We're on...

question: Hi, honey.
answer: Hi, Daddy.

question: What's new?
answer: Ms. Laufer gave me a star today.

question: Yeah? What for?
answer: For reading.

question: That's great... Little early for cartoons, isn't it?
answer: Okay.

question: Sweetheart, c'mon. C'mon.
answer: She was playing with my Pooh doll again...

question: Slow down. Slow down. Slow down. Breathe deep. Breathe deep. Slow down, honey. Slow down. Slow down.
answer: She was playing with the Pooh doll.

question: ...if you are, then I'll take Barbara to soccer and take you to dance after...
answer: I can take her.

question: Don't you have to be at the office?
answer: Is there any more rice...?

question: I'm sorry, darling, have you seen my coffee mug...?
answer: Try the car.

question: Uh, what are those boxes?
answer: I'm going to the store. You need anything?

question: What do you need at the store?
answer: Soy sauce...

question: Right now?
answer: That's my stuff from the office...

question: Why did you take your stuff from the office?
answer: I didn't want to leave it there...

question: I don't understand.
answer: I got fired this morning... Where else am I gonna take it?

question: Why? Who said?
answer: Thomas Sandefur...

question: What are we supposed to do...? What about our medical coverage; what about our health? What about our car payments? The payments on this house?
answer: There's a severance agreement... It includes cash payouts over time and continuing medical coverage... Sure you don't need anything?

question: He says you must not sit so close.
answer: What? I can't conduct an interview from back there.

question: You must move back your chair.
answer: Will you tell him that when I conduct an interview, I sit anywhere I damn please!

question: There is no interview.
answer: You! I'm talking to you!

question: ...everyone thinks Canadian Mounties ride horses and rescue ladies from rapids, Mike. They backed locals in Oka in a fight with Mohawks over building a golf course on their burial site. They beat up protesters at Kanasake... Where'd you hear that?
answer: It's Stuart...he's in Mexico City...

question: Let me call you back... Yeah, Stuart... What New York bank?
answer: No classes this morning?

question: Will he go on-camera and talk about the Mexico City branch?
answer: Hi, sweetheart...

question: Will independent sources corroborate that?
answer: Hello? Yeah...

question: Let me see this... No, 'cause I gotta know where you're going at all times.
answer: I can't... I've got to fly to Boston tomorrow. Two p.m. Great. Bye-bye.

question: ..."ignition propensity?" ...you understand any of this...?
answer: ...no...this looks like a table of temperatures... Who's this from?

question: ...it's anonymous. References to "P.M." It's got to be Philip Morris, huh?
answer: I have to take a shower.

question: Yeah. Oh, hi, Doug...it's Lowell. I'm doing this story on fire safety... People burning up from falling asleep smoking. I received a shitload of scientific papers from inside Philip Morris... Anonymous. You or anybody in FDA know someone who can translate this stuff into English for me? Mr. Wigand, please.
answer: Who's calling?

question: My name's Lowell Bergman... I'm --
answer: Did you say Berman?

question: No, Bergman...B.E.R.G.M.A.N.... I'm a producer with "60 Minutes"...
answer: "60 Minutes"?

question: Yeah.
answer: "60 Minutes," the television show?

question: Have you always lived in Louisville?
answer: Mr. Bergman? What did you want me to consult about? Who's that?

question: That's room service. They usually knock first. Come on in... Over here, please. How do you like your coffee? Black?
answer: Black, black... Look, I really don't have that much time...

question: Is there anything you want to know about me, Mr. Wigand...?
answer: Like what? Your sign? I know what I have to know.

question: Just so I know you know, when I talk to people in confidence, it stays that way.
answer: How did a radical journalist from Ramparts Magazine end up at CBS?

question: I still do the tough stories. "60 Minutes" reaches a lot of people.
answer: Let me see the documents... ...this is a Fire-Safety Product Study for Philip Morris. Burn rates...ignition propensity...things of this nature. I could very easily explain this to you in layman's terms, because it's from another company...

question: Far as you go where?
answer: This issue is a drop in the bucket. I can talk to you about what's in here. But I can't talk to you about anything else. I signed a confidentiality agreement. I honor agreements... Doesn't CBS have confidentiality agreements, Mr. Bergman?

question: Between journalists and management, yes, I believe they do...but I don't take that seriously. Where do you work?
answer: Did work.

question: Did work.
answer: How much would I get paid?

question: That, you have to discuss with CBS Business Affairs. But, for something like this, I would say anywhere between 10, 12 thousand.
answer: Should I just take the documents now?

question: If you want to do it.
answer: I worked as the head of Research and Development for Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company. I was a Corporate Vice President. Mr. Bergman...

question: ...come in earlier on Mike's Marine barracks line when he's talking to Sheikh Mussawi...
answer: You eating with us?

question: Yeah.
answer: Bring a tie so they'll let us in the front door...

question: Sorry. I'm accepting an award from the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation. It's going to kill the rest of my day. Jeff's a premiere golfer... What are you, a two handicap?
answer: Seven...

question: And, he gets out there and he has five strokes on us. He has more concentration than anybody I've ever met. It's spooky how he can concentrate.
answer: I'd rather play than talk about it. What did you want to see me about? I don't like being back here.

question: Jeffrey says exactly what's on his mind. Most people consider what they're saying...social skills... Jeffrey just charges right ahead. Now, I know you understood the nature of the confidentiality portion of your severance agreement with Brown & Williamson, Jeff...
answer: Chapter and verse.

question: Yeah, I know you do... You know, I came up through sales. One of the reasons I was a great salesman, was I never made a promise I couldn't keep. I knew that if I ever broke my promise I'd suffer the consequence...
answer: Is that a threat?

question: ...we worked together for, what was it, three years...? Now, the work we did here is confidential, not for public scrutiny...any more than are one's family matters...
answer: You threatening my family, now, too?

question: Now, don't be paranoid, Jeff. About the direction of research here, we may have had our differences of opinion...
answer: "Research..." You declare, as a badge of honor, you don't even know what makes water boil...

question: That's why we hire scientists...
answer: Okay. I don't believe you can maintain corporate integrity without confidentiality agreements. I was paid well for my work. The health and welfare benefits are good. The severance package is fair. I have no intention of violating my confidentiality agreement and disclosing that which I said I wouldn't.

question: I appreciate all that, Jeff. But, upon reflection...we've decided to expand our zone of comfort with you. So we've drafted a supplement to your agreement...it broadly defines and expands in more detail what is "confidential." Nobody will be able to say, "Well, hell's bells, Margaret, I didn't know that was a secret..." We're very serious about protecting our interests. We'd like you to sign it.
answer: And if I don't? Dr. Wigand. So, what you are saying is

question: Mrs. Wigand, how do you do?
answer: Jump in, quick, c'mon...

question: I'm Lowell Bergman. We spoke on the phone, remember? C'mere. I want to talk to you.
answer: Good. I want to talk to you. What do...

question: I did not burn you. I did not give you up to anyone!
answer: This is my house... In front of my wife, my kids?! What business do we have?

question: To straighten something out with you. Right here. Right now.
answer: So, you didn't mention my name? You haven't talked to anybody about me?

question: Why am I gonna mention your name?
answer: How did Brown & Williamson know I spoke to you...?

question: How the hell do I know about Brown & Williamson?
answer: It happened after I talked to you. I do not like coincidences!

question: And I don't like paranoid accusations! I'm a journalist. Think. Use your head. How do I operate as a journalist by screwing the people who could provide me with information before they provided me with it?
answer: You came all the way down here to tell me that?

question: No. I did not. Big Tobacco is a big story. And you got something important to say. I can tell. But, yes. I did. I came all the way down here to tell you
answer: Ride with me while I take the girls to school...

question: And, I'm unemployed. So I have to protect my medical coverage. ...so I left them a message this morning. Their expanded confidentiality agreement? I will sign it.
answer: They're afraid of you, aren't they?

question: They should be.
answer: Talk to me outside the zone of your agreement?

question: Like what?
answer: Like where'd you work before Brown & Williamson?

question: Johnson & Johnson. Union Carbide in Japan. I was general manager and director of new products. I speak Japanese. I was a director of corporate development at Pfizer. All health- related. What else? Outside the "zone"...?
answer: I don't know...you think the Knicks are gonna make it through the semi-finals?

question: For example. James Burke, the CEO of Johnson & Johnson...when he found out that some lunatic had put poison in Tylenol bottles, he didn't argue with the FDA... He didn't even wait for the FDA to tell him. He just pulled Tylenol off every shelf of every store right across America. Instantly. And then he developed the safety cap... Because, look, as a CEO, sure, he's gotta be a great businessman, right? But he's also a man of science. He's not going to allow his company...to put on the shelf...a product that might hurt people. Not like the Seven Dwarfs...
answer: Seven dwarfs?

question: The seven CEOs of Big Tobacco...they got up in front of Congress that time...it was on television...
answer: ...and swore under oath that they know nothing about addiction, disease...

question: It was on C-SPAN. Yeah.
answer: Okay, so, here you are...you go to work for tobacco. You come from corporate cultures where research, really, creative thinking, these are core values. You go to tobacco... Tobacco is a sales culture. Market and sell enormous volume. Go to a lot of golf tournaments. The hell with everything else. What are you doing? Why are you working for "tobacco" in the first place?

question: I can't talk about it. The work I was supposed to do...might have had some positive effect. I don't know...it could have been beneficial. Mostly, I got paid a lot. I took the money. My wife was happy. My kids had good medical. Good schools. Got a great house. I mean, what the hell is wrong with that...?
answer: Nothing's wrong with that. That's it; you're making money...you're providing for your family? What could be wrong with that?

question: I've always thought of myself...as a man of science. That's what's wrong with it.
answer: Then...you're in a state of conflict, Jeff. Because, look, here's how it lays out

question: I've got to go pick up the girls. They only had half a day...
answer: He referred to this...the Seven Dwarfs...

question: He referred to this...the Seven Dwarfs...
answer: What "Seven Dwarfs?"

question: The seven CEOs of Big Tobacco... Referred to this... Said they should be afraid of him... I assume, afraid of what he could reveal. Now, you tell me. What does this guy have to say that threatens these people?
answer: Well, it isn't "cigarettes are bad for you"...

question: Hardly new news.
answer: No shit.

question: Doesn't matter what he wants.
answer: Am I missing something here?

question: What do you mean, Mike?
answer: He's got a corporate secrecy agreement? Give me a break. This is a public-health issue, like an unsafe airframe on a passenger jet or...some company dumping cyanide into the East River. Issues like that? He can talk, we can air it. They've got no right to hide behind a corporate agreement. Pass the milk...

question: Hey, hey, hey, c'mon. C'mon. We can make this work for us. Okay? It's just...it's a smaller scale. Simpler...easier...more time. More time together. More time with the kids. More time for us, okay? It's just... Can you imagine me coming home from some job feeling good at the end of the day? This is gonna be better. This is gonna be better. Hey, baby. What's wrong?
answer: What's that outside, Daddy?

question: Did you see somebody or did you hear them?
answer: I heard them.

question: Where?
answer: In the backyard.

question: Good. You have kids?
answer: We have a couple. One's hers, one's mine. Everybody uses a different name. Modern marriage. How's Liane?

question: She's okay. Hold on a minute, Lowell... ...somebody...may be following me. I don't know. They came on the property...
answer: What do you mean followed you? Did you call the police?

question: I don't want to be paranoid... I mean, maybe it's a game. Some kind of mind game.
answer: Well, what do you really think, though?

question: No, you said you were going to call me tomorrow. So, what about?
answer: Oh, yes, yes, yes, I did...I wanted to talk to you. I wanted to hook up and talk to you. About what we were talking about in your car.

question: ...okay.
answer: Makes you feel good? Putting what you know to use?

question: How'd you know that, Lowell?
answer: It's obvious, isn't it? Hello. You there

question: Yeah... Look, thanks for talking. I'm sorry I woke you up.
answer: It's okay.

question: Lowell...? Who is this? Do not call here! Do not...
answer: What did you get us?

question: Tempura...
answer: Marcuse. Yeah. He was my mentor. He had a major influence on the New Left in the late '60s...and on me, personally.

question: Next to your father?
answer: My father? What the hell's that got to do with my father?

question: Is that why you became a journalist? Then you get to ask all the questions?
answer: You charge by the hour?

question: My father was a mechanical engineer...most ingenious man I ever knew.
answer: Well, my father left us when I was five- years old. He was not the most ingenious man I ever knew... Let's get back to Brown & Williamson. If you decide to go on "60 Minutes," I got to know everything about why you got fired.

question: Why?
answer: They're gonna dig up stuff from your past, they're gonna throw it at you. I got to know what they're gonna throw. You understand?

question: I drink. A couple of occasions more than I should have. I was cited for shoplifting once. But it was a mistake... I pushed Liane one time. We were both stressed out because of the pressure. She went to her mother's. I got fired because when I get angry I have difficulty censoring myself. And I don't like to be pushed around!
answer: I'm not pushing you around! I'm asking you questions.

question: I'm just a commodity to you, aren't I? I could be anything. Right? Anything worth putting on between commercials...
answer: ...to a network, probably, we're all commodities. To me? You are not a commodity. What you are is important.

question: No.
answer: You should. Because when you're done, a judgment is going to go down in the court of public opinion, my friend. And that's the power you have.

question: You believe that?
answer: I believe that? Yes, I believe that.

question: You believe that because you get information out to people...something happens?
answer: Yes.

question: Maybe that's just what you've been telling yourself all these years to justify having a good job? Having status? And maybe for the audience, it's just voyeurism? Something to do on a Sunday night. And maybe it won't change a fucking thing. And people like myself and my family are left hung out to dry. Used up! Broke, alone!
answer: Are you talking to me or did somebody else just walk in here?! I never abandoned a source!

question: I don't think you really understand --
answer: No, don't evade a choice you gotta make be questioning my reputation or "60 Minutes'" with this cheap skepticism!

question: I have to put my family's welfare on the line here, my friend! And what are you puttin' up? You're puttin' up words!
answer: Words! While you've been dickin' around at fucking company golf tournaments, I been out in the world, giving my word and backing it up with action.

question: I said I'd call the kids before they went to bed. Onisa...
answer: The stringer was supposed to be shooting B-roll on street cops in New Orleans. What's with all the horses? Don't any of these guys ride in cars or walk? What was he seeing?

question: Hold on... Mobile approach...this is Lear November 643. Over. Request a flight level 220, on a heading of 284 degrees. Over. Mr. Bergman?
answer: Yes, I'm right here. Could you call me back on a hard line?

question: Alright.
I'll call you then.
answer: What do we do with that?

question: ...you filed a lawsuit against tobacco on behalf of the State of Mississippi, did you not?
answer: That's right...

question: Well, I'm working with someone, now, who was the former head of research at Brown & Williamson, a former corporate officer there.
answer: What's your interest in this, Mr. Bergman?

question: Has he decided to go public? Because let me tell you, we've been doing this for three years now, and we've worked with a lot of corporate cases involving whistle-blowers, so we know... Big Tobacco will do everything in their power to stop him. So, is your man truly committed?
answer: Well, actually, no. Well, he's on the fence. That's the point.

question: Well, we'd certainly be interested in making his acquaintance, but without knowing what he's going to do...
answer: Well, would you want him to call you? Or, you want to call him? How do you want to do it?

question: It would be better if he called us.
answer: Yeah.

question: Alright?
answer: Okay. Thank you. Oh, we need cops on the street. We don't need them on horses.

question: Okay. Thank you. Oh, we need cops on the street. We don't need them on horses.
answer: I don't know what he was thinking.

question: Oh, for God's sake, what has this guy got, a horse fetish?
answer: Alright, alright.

question: Someone put a bullet in my mailbox.
answer: Jeff, call the FBI right away...

question: They do this with impunity!
answer: Jeff...

question: I'll call them, Lowell.
answer: Did you handle the round, Mr. Wigand?

question: Yes, I'm afraid I did.
answer: Do you own a gun, Mr. Wigand?

question: A gun? Yes.
answer: What caliber is your gun?

question: What caliber is my gun?
answer: Yes, sir. What caliber is your gun?

question: What does that have to do with the price of tea in China? You think I put that bullet in the mailbox myself...?
answer: If we could take a look, Mr. Wigand...

question: I don't think it's unconstitutional yet to own a gun. I'm a target shooter.
answer: That bullet was for a .38 caliber. Do you own a .38?

question: Yes, I do. A .38 Target Master. In my gun safe downstairs. A .45 Gold Cup. A .22 target pistol. So what?
answer: Do you have a history of emotional problems, Mr. Wigand?

question: You heard Mr. Sandefur say before Congress that he believed nicotine was not addictive...?
answer: ...I believe Mr. Sandefur perjured himself because I watched those testimonies very carefully.

question: All of us did. There was this whole line of people...whole line of CEOs up there all swearing.
answer: Part of the reason I'm here is I felt that their representation clearly misstated, at least within Brown & Williamson's representation, clearly misstated...what is common language within the company...we are in the nicotine delivery business.

question: And that's what cigarettes are for...?
answer: A delivery device for nicotine.

question: A delivery device for nicotine. Put it in your mouth, light it up, and you're gonna get your fix...
answer: You're gonna get your fix...

question: You're saying that Brown & Williamson manipulates and adjusts the nicotine fix, not by artificially adding nicotine, but by enhancing the effect of nicotine through the use of chemical elements such as ammonia...
answer: The process is known as "impact boosting..." While not spiking nicotine, they clearly manipulate it. There's extensive use of this technology, know as "ammonia chemistry." It allows for the nicotine to be more rapidly absorbed in the lung and therefore affect the brain and central nervous system. The straw that broke the camel's back for me and really put me in trouble with Sandefur was a compound called "coumarin." When I came on board at B&W, they had tried to transition from coumarin to a similar flavor that would give the same taste, and had been unsuccessful. I wanted it out immediately. I was told that it would affect sales, so I should mind my own business. I constructed a memo to Mr. Sandefur indicating I could not in conscience continue with coumarin in a product that we now knew, we had documentation, was similar to coumadin, a lung-specific carcinogen...

question: And you sent the document forward to Sandefur?
answer: I sent the document forward to Sandefur. I was told that we would continue to work on a substitute, we weren't going to remove it as it would impact sales, and that that was his decision.

question: In other words, you were charging Sandefur and Brown & Williamson with ignoring health considerations consciously...
answer: Most certainly.

question: And on March 24, Thomas Sandefur, CEO of Brown & Williamson had you fired. And the reason he gave you?
answer: Poor communication skills.

question: And, do you wish you hadn't come forward? You wish you hadn't blown the whistle?
answer: Yeah, there are times I wish I hadn't done it. There are times I feel compelled to do it. If you asked me would I do it again? Do I think it's worth it? Yeah, I think it's worth it. Hi. My name is Jeff Wigand. You can call me Mr. Wigand; you can call me Dr. Wigand--I have a Ph.D. in biochemistry and endocrinology; you can call me Jeff... Anything else you want to call me...you'll have to do so in private... Okay... I find chemistry to be magical. I find it an adventure. An exploration into the building blocks of our physical universe... So, how many of you have taken chemistry before? Okay...I've never taught it before, so we're gonna be fine.

question: Yeah, there are times I wish I hadn't done it. There are times I feel compelled to do it. If you asked me would I do it again? Do I think it's worth it? Yeah, I think it's worth it. Hi. My name is Jeff Wigand. You can call me Mr. Wigand; you can call me Dr. Wigand--I have a Ph.D. in biochemistry and endocrinology; you can call me Jeff... Anything else you want to call me...you'll have to do so in private... Okay... I find chemistry to be magical. I find it an adventure. An exploration into the building blocks of our physical universe... So, how many of you have taken chemistry before? Okay...I've never taught it before, so we're gonna be fine.
answer: Hello.

question: Mr. Scruggs, Jeff Wigand. Lowell Bergman said I should give you a call...
answer: My co-counsel, Ron Motley, and I have filed a lawsuit against the tobacco industry on behalf of the State of Mississippi to get the state reimbursed Medicaid costs for treating people with smoking-related illness. If you'd be interested in talking to us, we'd certainly like to talk to you...

question: I called Richard Scruggs in Mississippi...
answer: I heard.

question: I'm going to be a witness for them in their litigation. So I'm going to fly to Pascagoula to give a deposition...
answer: I know. I'm going to go there tonight...

question: Please don't wash your hands in the sink.
answer: Where should I wash them?

question: Use the bathroom.
answer: What's the difference...

question: That's for food. I don't think I can do this... I want to stand by my husband... I really do, Jeffrey. But I don't think I can do this anymore. I am so sorry...
answer: Can we talk about this when I get back?

question: Now, what this one is, is a temporary restraining order, a gag order, issued by a Kentucky court. Jeff Wigand, Michael Moore.
answer: Good to meet you, Dr. Wigand.

question: Mike's our Attorney General down here. I was just explaining to Jeff, they got a Kentucky court to issue a gag order to stop his deposition today.
answer: Right.

question: Now, they tried to get the Mississippi Court to honor it, but the judge threw it out... However, for you, there is a more perilous effect to the Kentucky gag order...
answer: Dr. Wigand, you do understand what could happen, don't you?

question: I can't seem to find...the criteria to decide. It's too big a decision to make without being resolved...in my own mind.
answer: Maybe things have changed...

question: What's changed?
answer: You mean...since this morning?

question: In other words, it acts as a drug?
answer: Object to the form of the question!

question: It acts as a drug on the body?
answer: Object to the form!

question: It acts as a...
answer: Object!

question: There an echo in here? Your objection's been recorded. She typed it into her little machine over there. It's on the record. So now I'll proceed with my deposition of my witness. Does it act as a drug?
answer: Dr. Wigand. I am instructing you... ...not to answer that question in accordance to the terms of the contractual obligations undertaken by you not to disclose any information about your work at the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company. And in accordance with the force and effect of the temporary restraining order that has been entered against you to by the court in the State of Kentucky! That means you don't talk! Mr. Motley, we have rights, here...

question: But one we have to check on, Mike. I've retained outside counsel to do exactly that. On a segment, I might add, that's already rife with problems...
answer: What does that mean? "Rife with -- ?"

question: I'm told unusual promises were made to Wigand.
answer: No, only that we would hold the story until it was safe for him...

question: And, I'm told there are questions as to our "star witness'" veracity.
answer: His "veracity" was good enough for the State of Mississippi.

question: Our standards have to be higher than anyone else's, because we are the standard...for everyone else...
answer: Well, as a "standard"...I'll hang with "is the guy telling the truth?"

question: Well, with tortious interference, I'm afraid...the greater the truth, the greater the damage.
answer: Come again?

question: They own the information he's disclosing. The truer it is, the greater the damage to them. If he lied, he didn't disclose their information. And the damages are smaller.
answer: Is this "Alice in Wonderland"?

question: Hello, Lowell, Mike, Don. There has been so much soul searching about this Wigand, I've decided we should cut an alternate version of the show without his interview.
answer: So, what happened to Ms. Caperelli's checking with outside counsel first, all that crap?

question: That's happening. And, hopefully we won't have to use the alternate, but we should have it in the can.
answer: I'm not touching my film...

question: I'm afraid you are.
answer: No, I'm not...

question: We're doing this with or without you, Lowell. If you like, I can assign another producer to edit your show...
answer: Since when has the paragon of investigative journalism allowed lawyers to determine the news content on "60 Minutes"?

question: I'm not implying. I'm quoting. More vested interests... "Persons Who Will Profit From This Merger... Ms. Helen Caperelli, General Counsel of CBS News, 3.9 million. Mr. Eric Kluster, President of CBS News, 1.4 million..."
answer: Are you suggesting that she and Eric are influenced by money?

question: Oh, no, of course they're not influenced by money. They work for free. And you are a Volunteer Executive Producer.
answer: CBS does not do that. And, you're questioning our journalistic integrity?!

question: No, I'm questioning your hearing! You hear "reasonable" and "tortious interference." I hear... "Potential Brown & Williamson lawsuit jeopardizing the sale of CBS to Westinghouse." I hear... "Shut the segment down. Cut Wigand loose. Obey orders. And fuck off...!" That's what I hear.
answer: You're exaggerating!

question: I am? You pay me to go get guys like Wigand, to draw him out. To get him to trust us, to get him to go on television. I do. I deliver him. He sits. He talks. He violates his own fucking confidentiality agreement. And he's only the key witness in the biggest public health reform issue, maybe the biggest, most-expensive corporate-malfeasance case in U.S. history. And Jeffrey Wigand, who's out on a limb, does he go on television and tell the truth? Yes. Is it newsworthy? Yes. Are we gonna air it? Of course not. Why? Because he's not telling the truth? No. Because he is telling the truth. That's why we're not going to air it. And the more truth he tells, the worse it gets!
answer: You are a fanatic. An anarchist. You know that? If we can't have a whole show, then I want half a show rather than no show. But oh, no, not you. You won't be satisfied unless you're putting the company at risk!

question: C'mon, what are you? And are you a businessman? Or are you a newsman?! Because that happens to be what Mike and I do for a living...
answer: Lowell.

question: "Put the corporation at risk"...? Give me a fucking break!
answer: Lowell.

question: These people are putting our whole reason for doing what we do...on the line!
answer: Lowell!

question: What?
answer: I'm with Don on this.

question: What's wrong?
answer: They're killing the Wigand interview...

question: What?!
answer: They're pretending it's process. Bullshit, it's foregone.

question: What are you and Mike going to do?
answer: I'm alone on this...

question: Oh, baby... Jeffrey Wigand...
answer: Jeffrey...

question: Jeffrey, how are you? How's the family, okay?
answer: There is - there is no family.

question: What do you mean there is no family?
answer: Liane has filed for divorce... And, so, I moved out... I see the girls a couple of days a week...

question: Where you staying now?
answer: Our favorite hotel, honey... I checked into Room 930. Odd choice? Huh?

question: Our favorite hotel, honey... I checked into Room 930. Odd choice? Huh?
answer: I don't know how to say this, Jeff, except to just say it right out, so I'll say it. They do not want to air it.

question: What?!
answer: B & W may have threatened litigation... CBS is on the block... But you, I mean, I know how...

question: No.
answer: No? No, what?

question: I do not think that you "know" for me...what it is to walk in my shoes... ...for my kids to have seen it...for them to know why I've put them through what I did...the public airing of that...the testament to why I did what I did...you're telling me is not going to see the light of day.
answer: Jeff...

question: Jeff...
answer: So, what are you going to do?

question: Well, what do you think I'm going to do? Quit in protest? I'm not going to do that.
answer: You're taking "no" for an answer?

question: No. I'm not going to take "no" for an answer. No.
answer: Then what are you going to do?

question: I'm staying right here. Doing my job. Fighting to get my show on the air. You don't like it? Hey, I'll tell you what...fire my ass...
answer: End up in a high-profile lawsuit with Lowell, the First Amendment martyr? I don't think so. Take a look at this... This is a summary of a dossier that's being prepared. He would lie about his whole life...? Who's going to believe him about anything he says...? The Wall Street Journal's doing a major story and I think the Post. You backed the wrong horse...

question: Jeff! Wake the fuck up! Everybody is on the line here. If they can catch you in a lie, they can paint everything with that brush. Do you understand? Everything you say!
answer: I told the truth!

question: Everything...you...say! And I can't defend you, man, with one hand tied behind my back! Because you keep from me...what they can discover. And they will discover everything! Believe me.
answer: ...I was young. I was young...confused... We didn't handle it the right way...

question: She sued you for back payments of child support?
answer: She did not sue me. We had a dispute over money... I settled it, she dropped the complaint... Any other questions?

question: Yes. Did you lie about being on the American Judo Team in the Olympics?
answer: What?

question: Some public relations guy got a hold of a tape of an interview...where you're saying you were on the American Judo Team in the Olympics...?
answer: What kind of shit is this? I was not on the team, I sparred with the Olympic Team...okay?

question: Alright...the ABC Telemarketing Company?
answer: ABC...?

question: ABC Telemarketing Company.
answer: A can opener! A $39.95 can opener. I cancelled payment... It was junk. You ever bounce a check, Lowell? You ever look at another woman's tits? You ever cheat a little on your taxes? Whose life, if you look at it under a microscope, doesn't have any flaws...?

question: That's the whole point, Jeffrey. That's the whole point. Anyone's. Everyone's. They are gonna look under every rock, dig up every flaw, every mistake you've ever made. They are going to distort and exaggerate everything you've ever done, man. Don't you understand?
answer: What does this have to do with my testimony?

question: That's not the point.
answer: What does this have to do with my testimony?! I told the truth! It's valid and true and provable!

question: That's not the fucking point, whether you told the truth or not! Hello...?
answer: I told the truth... I told the truth. I've got to teach class. I've got to go. I've got to teach class.

question: And I've got to refute every fucking accusation made in this report before The Wall Street Journal runs. I am trying to protect you, man!
answer: Well, I hope you improve your batting average.

question: You caught me in a news meeting.
answer: Well, are you or are you not, Charlie?

question: You bet we are. And I can't talk to you now.
answer: We gotta hook up.

question: Sure. Where?
answer: P.J.'s.

question: I'll be there.
answer: Yeah, I got it. 500 pages of it. They looked in every corner of this guy's life...from a spousal abuse charge, to shoplifting, to a traffic ticket he got once for running a red light. It's Terry Lenzner's outfit, IGI. Jack, listen to me. Their strategy To make it even a little more attractive, I don't know if you're ever gonna get paid. That's a good question. "Is there any truth to any of it?" I doubt it. Soon. That's great, Jack.

question: Yeah, I got it. 500 pages of it. They looked in every corner of this guy's life...from a spousal abuse charge, to shoplifting, to a traffic ticket he got once for running a red light. It's Terry Lenzner's outfit, IGI. Jack, listen to me. Their strategy To make it even a little more attractive, I don't know if you're ever gonna get paid. That's a good question. "Is there any truth to any of it?" I doubt it. Soon. That's great, Jack.
answer: Hey, Lowell.

question: How are you, Jim?
answer: Hey, listen, I hear you guys are sitting on something sensational over there.

question: Really? Hi, Joan.
answer: Hi, baby.

question: Catch you later. When's your deadline?
answer: Monday.

question: Push it.
answer: What? Forget it.

question: It's a smear campaign, Charlie.
answer: It's drawn from a selectively circulated...

question: Oh, it's real selective...about as hard to get a hold of as the Manhattan phone book.
answer: Well, it's authoritative and is overwhelmingly documented.

question: And it's bullshit. And if I'm right, are you going to put the Journal's reputation behind a story that's going to blow up in your face?
answer: I'll take a look at what you got. But I'm not moving any deadlines 'cause you say so.

question: Yeah. Catch you later.
answer: What the hell are you doing?

question: What does it look like I'm doing? I'm editing.
answer: No, not that. I'm talking about the Associated Press. They got this story that we pulled this interview and they talked to Mike and I. Did you tell them that we were lying?

question: No. I should have. I told them I disagreed with you, Mike and Kluster that this segment is as good as the original. I'm not lying for you. I'm not gonna shut up for you. Not on any of it.
answer: Hey! I'm not going to fire you, okay? Take a vacation. Now!

question: What do you want to buy him for a gift?
answer: He's into kind of little cars, that...

question: That remote control thing?
answer: Yeah.

question: Alright, we'll do that tomorrow.
answer: Mom.

question: Yes, baby?
answer: There's Dad, on TV.

question: "The former executive has reason to bet on being sued, for major cigarette manufacturers..."
answer: Yeah.

question: You disappeared on me. How long you staying?
answer: I disappeared on you?

question: Alright. What did you think?
answer: I think it was a disgrace. Alright. Get me the manager's office...

question: I think I need to call the police. He won't respond...
answer: No, no. Don't call the police! Just tell him I'm on the phone with you... My name is Lowell Bergman... Just tell him that. Did he hear you?

question: You're breaking up. I can't hear you.
answer: What about now?

question: What?
answer: Hello, can you hear me now? What's happening?!

question: He doesn't seem to be listening...
answer: Alright, now listen to me. I want you - I want you to tell him, in these words

question: I can't say that!
answer: No, you can. Tell him to get on the fucking phone!

question: No, you can. Tell him to get on the fucking phone!
answer: You manipulated me into this...!

question: That's bullshit, Jeff!
answer: You greased the rails!

question: I greased the rails for a guy who wanted to say yes. I helped him to say yes. Alright. You're not a robot, Jeff! That's all. You got a mind of your own, don't you?
answer: "Up to you, Jeffrey. That's the power you have, Jeffrey. Vital insider information the American public need to know." Lowell Bergman, the hot show who never met a source he couldn't turn around.

question: I fought for you...and I still fight for you.
answer: You fought for me...?! ...you manipulated me...into where I am now...staring at the Brown & Williamson Building. It's all dark. Except the 10th floor! That's the legal department. That's where they fuck with my life!

question: Jeffrey, where you going with this? So where you goin'? You are important to a lot of people, Jeffrey. You think about that. You think about them. I'm running out of heroes, man... Guys like you are in short supply.
answer: Yeah, guys like you, too. Where are you, anyway?

question: I'm on a leave of absence. Forced vacation.
answer: You try and have a good time.

question: Yeah. Yeah, I will. "I'm Lowell Bergman, I'm from '60 Minutes.'" You know, you take the "60 Minutes" out of that sentence, nobody returns your phone call. Maybe Wigand's right. Maybe I'm hooked. What am I hooked on? The rush? "60 Minutes"? What the hell for? Infotainment. It's so fucking useless, all of it.
answer: So, it's a big country with a free press. You can go work somewhere else.

question: Free press? Press is free...for anyone who owns one. Larry Tisch has a free press.
answer: Get some perspective, Lowell.

question: I got perspective.
answer: No, you do not.

question: From my perspective, what's been going on and what I've been doing is ridiculous. It's half-measures.
answer: You're not listening. Really know what you're going to do before you do it.

question: You mean, "60 Minutes" is letting CBS corporate decide what is or is not news? What's Wallace think about this, or Hewitt, or...?
answer: How prominent? What kind of placement?

question: Oh, c'mon, Lowell. This is The New York Times. I don't know...
answer: Well, until you do, all I can tell you is what you already know...they will not air an interview.

question: Here's how it works. You ask me questions. I tell you if you're wrong.
answer: Okay. Lowell?

question: Yeah?
answer: You're sure you want to do this?

question: Why?
answer: Hey, it doesn't work? You've burned your bridges, man.

question: You ready...?
answer: Okay... About this whistle-blower... Did Mike and Don go along with the corporate decision?

question: Did I tell you you were wrong?
answer: No. I'm assuming the cave-in begins with the threat of litigation from Big Tobacco. Are we talking...are we talking Brown & Williamson, here?

question: Did I get you up?
answer: No, I usually sit around in my hotel room, dressed like this at 5:30 in the morning, sleepy look on my face.

question: How many shows have we done? Huh? C'mon, how many?
answer: Oh, lots.

question: Yeah, that's right.
answer: But in all that time, Mike, did you ever get off a plane, walk into a room, and find that a source for a story changed his mind? Lost his heart? Walked out on us? Not one fucking time! You want to know why?

question: I see a rhetorical question on the horizon.
answer: I'm going to tell you why. Because when I tell someone I'm going to do something, I deliver.

question: Oh, how fortunate I am to have Lowell Bergman's moral tutelage to point me down the shining path. To show me the way.
answer: Oh, please, Mike...

question: Give me a break!
answer: No, you give me a break! I never left a source hung out to dry, ever. Abandoned. Not 'til right fucking now! When I came on this job, I came with my word intact. I'm gonna leave with my word intact. Fuck the rules of the game! Hell, you're supposed to know me, Mike. What the hell did you expect? You expect me to lie down? Back off? What, get over it?

question: In the real world, when you get to where I am, there are other considerations...
answer: Like what? Corporate responsibility? What, are we talking celebrity here?

question: I'm not talking celebrity, vanity, CBS. I'm talking about when you're nearer the end of your life than the beginning. Now, what do you think you think about then? The future? "In the future I'm going to do this? Become that?" What "future"? No. What you think is
answer: Mike...in my...
